title: What is the transformative power of education? - Quora

response.answer_text: Wow. I could write a whole book to answer this question. Here’s my quick take: Education challenges every belief you have, and oddly enough, makes you more confident as a person because you know your beliefs can withstand scrutiny. “Challenges” does not necessarily mean “question”, in fact it could mean “explain”, and more often than not, question and explain give you the same result. It questions you to prove what you once blatantly accepted as fact and forces you to provide validity to your own self. It contorts your thinking until you’re unsure of yourself, which only propels you to work harder to provide reasoning and evidence for the simplest truths in life. You find it necessary to stand on the solid ground of reason because it bothers you to submit to everything said by a teacher or written in a textbook without first understanding it yourself. And then you realize you are a changed person. If you have succeeded in proving to yourself that the oceans tides are caused by the relationship between the earth and the moon and that there was indeed a highly intelligent and advanced civilization in modern day America in the pre-Columbian era then you feel that rush of being apart of the body of knowledge. You know that knowledge doesn’t accept bias or blindly follow the musings of others. You can think for yourself. Your conjectures are meaningful because you are confident in your assertions and can provide ample evidence behind them. As a person, you are transformed into an insightful, inquisitive, and emboldened human being, fully aware of the power of your knowledge. Truly, the armor of an educated mind is one to be reckoned with.

From Somalia to Guatemala, Jordan to Thailand, UNESCO’s work and efforts are fuelled by inspiring stories from around the world on the transformative power of education. Behind all the facts and figures on education and the progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals, there are real people around the world whose fates are being altered every day by learning opportunities. The much-celebrated Sustainable Development Goals 4 (SGD4) is one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that the United Nations adopted for the target date 2030 almost 5 years ago. At its core there are 17 sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), which are urgent calls for action by all countries-developed and developing in global partnership. In these 17 Goals #SDG4 is the education Goal that countries will have to reach for the 2030 agenda.
